awd_titl_txt: Fracture density and grain size controls on the relief structure of bedrock landscapes
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantifying the connection between rock material properties and the topography of mountain ranges is critical for understanding how climate and tectonics influence landscapes and for predicting natural hazards. However, incorporating rock strength into landscape evolution models has been a challenging problem. This is due in part to difficulties in defining appropriate metrics to describe rock strength, and because the factors that determine rock strength vary in importance depending on erosion process. This project aims to address this knowledge gap by testing the hypothesis that in steep landscapes, rock strength exerts a first order control on landscape-scale erodibility through the influence of fracture density on bedrock hillslopes and the resulting grain size distribution of sediment delivered to channels.
 
By comparing topographic metrics of hillslope and channel relief with erosion rates determined from cosmogenic nuclide concentrations in stream sediment, this project will characterize differences in erodibility between two landscapes in Southern California with similar topography, rock type, and climate, but strongly contrasting tectonic history and bedrock fracture density. This project will take advantage of new ground-based photogrammetry techniques and analysis of high-resolution airborne lidar data to upscale field observations and measurements to entire landscapes. Development and testing of novel point-cloud and image-based analysis techniques will provide training and experience for geoscience undergraduates through classroom laboratory exercises and independent research projects. Results from this project will provide a framework for making progress on the challenging task of expanding site-specific correlations between relief and erosion rate to regions with differing rock strength and climate, and inform provocative hypotheses regarding potential feedbacks between tectonic setting and bedrock fracturing that limit the height of mountain ranges.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:Understanding how rock strength influences erosion processes is a longstanding challenge in geomorphology. Despite widespread appreciation of its importance for interpreting the climate and tectonic history encoded in the topography of mountain ranges, rock strength at landscape scale has proven difficult to constrain. We addressed this knowledge gap by focusing on two visible expressions of rock material properties in steep, rocky landscapes: 1) bedrock fracture density, which influences the strength of exposed cliffs on hillsides; and 2) sediment grain size, which is influenced by bedrock fracture density and influences erosion rates in rivers.


Intellectual merit:In this project, we analyzed the topography, erosion rates, and rock properties of two granitic mountain ranges in southern California that differ mainly in the degree of bedrock fracturing as expressed in abundant hillside cliff exposures. Using high-resolution 3D imaging of 50 cliff faces collected in the field, we quantified a 5-fold difference in fracture density between the eastern San Gabriel Mountains (highly fractured) and the northern San Jacinto Mountains (less fractured). This 5-fold contrast in fracture density is expressed as bedrock cliff faces that are 2-3x taller and soil-mantled slopes that erode 2-3x slower in less fractured bedrock. Using low-altitude commercial air photos and field-based surveys, we measured the size distribution of surface sediment at 274 locations on hillslopes and in channels and showed how the size distribution of sediment depends primarily on bedrock fracture spacing. The coarser sediment mantling channels in landscapes with less-fractured bedrock leads to slower erosion rates as measured by 10Be concentrations in stream sediments, in agreement with a river incision model that accounts for these sediment effects. Overall, the data from this project indicate the importance of accounting for the coupling between hillslopes and channels when quantifying the influence of rock properties on landscape evolution. Of particular note is the importance of sediment grain size as an indirect indicator of rock strength that is increasingly measurable at the landscape scale with high resolution imagery.


Broader impacts:The project formed the core of one PhD dissertation and involved training and field experience for three additional graduate students. Throughout the project, undergraduate students at Penn State were involved through the Pennsylvania Space Grant Consortium Research Internship Program and through supervision of independent research leading to three senior theses and co-authorship on published outputs.
